Questions: What is the role of the NMC?
Option a: To represent or campaign on behalf of nurses and midwifes
Option b: To regulate hospital or other healthcare settings in the UK
Option c: To regulate health care assistance
Option d: To regulate nurses and midwives in the UK to protect thepublic
Explanation: The Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) is the independent regulator for nurses and midwives in the UK. Its primary role is to protect the public by setting standards of education, practice, and conduct, and ensuring that professionals on its register uphold these standards.
SUBJECT: Core Professional Role

Questions: What is the purpose of The NMC Code?
Option a: It outlines specific tasks or clinical procedures
Option b: It ascertains in detail a nurse's or midwife's clinical expertise
Option c: It is a tool for educating prospective nurses and midwives
Option d: It contains the professional standards that registered nurses, midwives and nursing associates must uphold.
Explanation: The NMC Code presents the professional standards that all registered nurses, midwives, and nursing associates must uphold. It is structured around four key themes: prioritizing people, practicing effectively, preserving safety, and promoting professionalism and trust.
SUBJECT: Professional Standards

Questions: All are purposes of NMC except:
Option a: NMC's role is to regulate nurses and midwives in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
Option b: It sets standards of education, training, conduct and performance so that nurses and midwives can deliver high quality healthcarethroughout their careers.
Option c: It makes sure that nurses and midwives keep their skills and knowledge up to date and uphold its professional standards.
Option d: It is responsible for regulating hospitals or other healthcare settings.
Explanation: While the NMC regulates the professionals (nurses and midwives) who work within healthcare settings, it does not regulate the settings themselves. Healthcare settings in England are regulated by the Care Quality Commission (CQC).
SUBJECT: Professional Regulation

Questions: The UK regulator for nursing & midwifery professions within the UK with a stated aim to protect the health & well-being of the public is:
Option b: NMC
Option c: BMC
Explanation: The Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) is the specific regulator for the nursing and midwifery professions in the United Kingdom. The General Medical Council (GMC) regulates doctors.
SUBJECT: Professional Bodies

Questions: Which of the following agency set the standards of education, training and conduct and performance for nurses and midwives in the UK?
Option b: DH
Option c: CQC
Explanation: The NMC is the statutory body responsible for setting and monitoring the standards for education, training, conduct, and performance for nurses and midwives in the UK.
SUBJECT: Professional Standards

Questions: What do you mean by code of ethics?
Option a: Legal activities of a registered nurse
Option b: A set of moral principles that govern a person's behavior or the conducting of an activity
Option c: A document that outlines the rules of an organization
Explanation: A code of ethics provides a framework of moral principles to guide professional practice, ensuring that practitioners act with integrity and in the best interests of those they care for. The NMC Code is a prime example of a code of ethics in nursing.
SUBJECT: Professionalism

Questions: When can a nurse delegate tasks to other people?
Option a: When the nurse is too busy to complete the tasks
Option b: When the other person is a student nurse
Option c: When the nurse is confident that the other person has the necessary skills and knowledge
Option d: Never, a nurse must complete all tasks themselves
Explanation: Nurses can delegate tasks but remain accountable. Delegation must be safe and in the best interests of the patient. The nurse must be satisfied that the person the task is delegated to has the knowledge, skills, and competence to perform it safely and effectively.
SUBJECT: Delegation & Accountability

Questions: What is the main purpose of revalidation?
Option a: To test a nurse's clinical skills
Option b: To provide a way for nurses and midwives to demonstrate their continued fitness to practise
Option c: To check if a nurse has completed enough training courses
Explanation: Revalidation is the process that allows nurses and midwives to demonstrate that they practice safely and effectively. It is a process of ongoing professional development and reflection to maintain their registration with the NMC.
SUBJECT: Professional Development

Questions: Which of the following is NOT one of the four themes of the NMC Code?
Option b: Practise effectively
Option c: Preserve safety
Explanation: The four themes of the NMC Code are: Prioritise people, Practise effectively, Preserve safety, and Promote professionalism and trust. 'Promote leadership' is not one of the four core themes.
SUBJECT: Professional Standards

Questions: What should a nurse do if they have a conscientious objection to a particular procedure?
Option a: Refuse to care for the patient
Option b: Inform their employer and colleagues and ensure that patient care is not compromised
Option c: Perform the procedure anyway
Option d: Ask the patient to request another nurse
Explanation: Nurses have the right to a conscientious objection, but they must inform their employer and ensure that a patient's care is not compromised and that they are not left without the care they need. The nurse's primary duty is to the patient.
SUBJECT: Ethics & Professionalism

Questions: What are the 6 C's of nursing?
Option a: Care, Compassion, Competence, Communication, Courage, Commitment
Option b: Caring, Comfort, Competence, Communication, Courage, Commitment
Option c: Care, Compassion, Competence, Communication, Courage, Confidentiality
Option d: Care, Compassion, Competence, Communication, Courage, Co-operation
Explanation: The 6Cs were introduced to integrate core values into patient care in the NHS. They stand for Care, Compassion, Competence, Communication, Courage, and Commitment.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A newly registered nurse is assigned to a busy ward. She is feeling overwhelmed. Which 'C' should she focus on to manage her feelings and responsibilities?
Option b: Courage
Option c: Commitment
Explanation: Courage enables a nurse to do the right thing for people they care for, to speak up when they have concerns, and to innovate in the face of adversity.

Questions: Which of the following is NOT a part of the NMC's Code of Conduct?
Option b: Practise Effectively
Option c: Promote Professionalism and Trust
Explanation: "Provide Palliative Care" is a specific nursing skill, not one of the four main themes of the NMC Code of Conduct.

Questions: A nurse witnesses a colleague acting unprofessionally. What should be the nurse's first action?
Option b: Report the colleague to the NMC immediately
Option c: Speak to the colleague privately
Explanation: The principle of 'Preserve Safety' encourages addressing issues directly and promptly. Speaking to the colleague first may resolve the issue, but it must be escalated if patient safety is at risk.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the legal requirement for obtaining consent from a patient before a procedure?
Option b: The patient must be conscious
Option c: The patient must have the capacity to make the decision
Explanation: For consent to be valid, the person must be able to make the decision (have capacity), be given all the relevant information, and give consent voluntarily.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A patient who does not speak English requires an explanation of a procedure. What is the best course of action?
Option a: Use a family member to translate
Option b: Use a professional interpreter service
Option c: Use hand gestures and diagrams
Option d: Wait until a doctor is available
Explanation: Using a professional, impartial interpreter is essential to ensure the patient fully understands the information and can provide informed consent. Family members may not be impartial or have sufficient medical terminology knowledge.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the primary purpose of the Data Protection Act 2018 in a healthcare setting?
Option a: To prevent patients from accessing their health records
Option b: To protect personal and sensitive information
Option c: To allow free sharing of patient data between organizations
Option d: To ensure all health records are digital
Explanation: The Data Protection Act 2018 (which incorporates the GDPR) governs how personal information is used and protected. In healthcare, this is crucial for maintaining patient confidentiality.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: Under what circumstances can a nurse break confidentiality?
Option a: When a patient's family asks for information
Option b: When a serious crime may be prevented
Option c: When a colleague asks for information for their own interest
Explanation: Confidentiality can be breached without a patient's consent if it is in the public interest, such as to prevent a serious crime or if there is a risk of serious harm to the patient or others.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the main aim of the Mental Capacity Act 2005?
Option a: To allow doctors to make all decisions for patients with mental health issues
Option b: To protect and empower people who may lack the mental capacity to make their own decisions
Option c: To make it easier to detain people under the Mental Health Act
Option d: To give family members the right to make decisions for their relatives
Explanation: The MCA is designed to protect and empower individuals who may lack capacity. It starts with the assumption that everyone has capacity, and any act done for someone who lacks capacity must be in their best interests.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A patient with dementia repeatedly tries to leave the ward. What is the most appropriate initial action?
Option a: Restrain the patient in their bed
Option b: Administer a sedative
Option c: Try to understand the reason for their behavior and use distraction techniques
Explanation: The least restrictive principle should always be applied. Understanding the cause of the behavior and using communication and distraction techniques is the first and most appropriate response.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What does the term 'safeguarding' refer to in a healthcare context?
Option b: Protecting people's health, wellbeing and human rights, and enabling them to live free from harm, abuse and neglect
Option c: Keeping medical records secure
Explanation: Safeguarding means protecting vulnerable adults or children from harm, abuse, and neglect. It is a key professional responsibility for all healthcare staff.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: Which of the following is a key principle of safe medication administration?
Option a: The 5 Rights (Right Patient, Right Drug, Right Dose, Right Route, Right Time)
Option b: Administering medication as quickly as possible
Option c: Allowing patients to administer their own medication
Option d: Only administering medication prescribed by a senior doctor
Explanation: The '5 Rights' (often expanded to more) are a fundamental safety check to reduce medication errors.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A nurse makes a medication error. What is their professional duty?
Option a: To report the error immediately to the person in charge and the doctor, and to document it
Option b: To correct the error on the next dose
Option c: To wait and see if the patient has any adverse effects
Option d: To ask a colleague not to say anything
Explanation: The professional duty of candour requires healthcare professionals to be open and honest when something goes wrong. This includes reporting errors promptly and documenting them.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the purpose of clinical governance?
Option a: To ensure the hospital is financially stable
Option b: A framework through which NHS organisations are accountable for continuously improving the quality of their services
Option c: To manage staff holidays and rota
Explanation: Clinical governance is a systematic approach to maintaining and improving the quality of patient care within a health system.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: Which of these is a key component of effective hand hygiene?
Option b: Using alcohol gel on visibly soiled hands
Option c: Washing hands for at least 20 seconds
Option d: Wearing gloves instead of washing hands
Explanation: Effective handwashing technique, including washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, is crucial for infection prevention and control.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the correct procedure for disposing of sharps (needles, etc.)?
Option a: In a standard clinical waste bag
Option b: In a designated, puncture-proof sharps container
Option c: By recapping the needle and placing it in a general waste bin
Option d: In a yellow clinical waste bag
Explanation: Sharps must be disposed of immediately at the point of use in a designated sharps container to prevent needlestick injuries.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A patient has a 'Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation' (DNACPR) order in place. What does this mean?
Option a: The patient should not receive any medical treatment
Option b: The patient will not be resuscitated in the event of cardiac or respiratory arrest
Option c: The patient is expected to die within 24 hours
Option d: The patient's family can override the decision
Explanation: A DNACPR is a medical decision that CPR will not be attempted. It does not affect any other aspect of the patient's care or treatment.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the role of a 'next of kin' in medical decision-making in the UK?
Option a: They have the legal right to make decisions for the patient
Option b: They are consulted for their opinion, but have no legal decision-making power unless they have Lasting Power of Attorney
Option c: They must consent to all treatments
Option d: They can override a patient's competent refusal of treatment
Explanation: Unless the 'next of kin' holds a Lasting Power of Attorney for health and welfare, their role is to advise and be consulted. They cannot make decisions on behalf of a competent adult.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A patient is refusing a blood transfusion for religious reasons, but it is life-saving. What is the correct action?
Option b: Ask the hospital chaplain to convince them
Option c: Respect their autonomous decision, if they have capacity
Option d: Seek a court order to override their decision
Explanation: A competent adult has the right to refuse treatment, even if that decision results in their death. This is a fundamental principle of patient autonomy.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the primary purpose of a risk assessment in a clinical setting?
Option a: To blame staff when things go wrong
Option b: To identify, analyse and evaluate potential hazards to patients and staff
Option c: To complete paperwork for auditing purposes
Explanation: Risk assessments are a proactive process to identify potential harm and implement measures to reduce the risk.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: Which of the following is a common symptom of sepsis?
Option b: High temperature
Option c: Confusion
Explanation: Sepsis can present with a variety of symptoms, including fever or low temperature, confusion, low blood pressure, and a high heart rate. It is a life-threatening condition.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the 'SBAR' tool used for?
Option b: Structuring communication between healthcare professionals
Option c: Documenting care plans
Explanation: SBAR (Situation, Background, Assessment, Recommendation) is a communication tool used to provide clear, concise information, especially in critical situations.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A nurse is concerned about a patient's deteriorating condition. The doctor on call does not seem to be taking the concerns seriously. What should the nurse do?
Option b: Follow the formal chain of command for escalation
Option c: Ask the patient's family to complain
Explanation: Patient safety is paramount. If a nurse's concerns are not being addressed, they have a professional duty to escalate them through the established channels (e.g., to a more senior nurse or doctor).
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the purpose of reflective practice in nursing?
Option b: To learn from experiences and improve future practice
Option c: To complete a mandatory yearly essay
Option d: To share patient stories with colleagues
Explanation: Reflective practice is a key part of professional development. It involves thinking about experiences to understand them and learn from them, which leads to improvements in care.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: Which of the following is a protected characteristic under the Equality Act 2010?
Option b: Age
Option c: Appearance
Explanation: The Equality Act 2010 lists nine protected characteristics, which include age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage and civil partnership, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sex, and sexual orientation.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A patient complains of being in pain. What is the most reliable indicator of their pain?
Option b: The nurse's own judgement
Option c: The patient's self-report
Option d: The opinion of the patient's family
Explanation: Pain is a subjective experience. The patient's self-report is the most reliable indicator of their pain level and should be the primary guide for assessment and management.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the NICE (National Institute for Health and Care Excellence)?
Option b: An organisation that provides national guidance and advice to improve health and social care
Option c: A charity that funds medical research
Option d: The regulator for doctors in the UK
Explanation: NICE produces evidence-based guidance and advice for health, public health, and social care practitioners.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A patient is at high risk of developing pressure sores. Which of the following is a key preventative measure?
Option a: Keeping the patient in one position to avoid friction
Option b: Regular repositioning
Option c: Massaging the bony areas
Explanation: Regular repositioning of the patient is a crucial intervention to relieve pressure on bony prominences and prevent the development of pressure sores.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) used to assess?
Option b: Pain level
Option c: Risk of falls
Explanation: The GCS is a neurological scale used to reliably assess a person's level of consciousness after a brain injury. It assesses eye, verbal, and motor responses.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A nurse is documenting care in a patient's notes. What is a key principle of good record-keeping?
Option a: Records should be clear, accurate, and contemporaneous
Option b: Use abbreviations as much as possible to save time
Option c: Document at the end of the shift
Option d: Leave blank spaces for others to add notes later
Explanation: Good record-keeping is essential for patient safety and continuity of care. Records must be clear, accurate, and made at the time of the event or as soon as possible afterwards.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the difference between an 'advocate' and a 'chaperone'?
Option b: An advocate speaks for the patient, while a chaperone is present for examinations to protect both patient and professional
Option c: An advocate is a legal role, while a chaperone is informal
Option d: An advocate is for children, a chaperone is for adults
Explanation: An advocate helps a patient express their views and wishes, while a chaperone is a neutral third party present during an intimate examination.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the main purpose of the NHS Constitution?
Option a: To set out the pay scales for NHS staff
Option b: To describe the purpose, principles, and values of the NHS in England
Option c: To list all the treatments available on the NHS
Option d: To outline the structure of the Department of Health
Explanation: The NHS Constitution for England establishes the principles and values of the NHS. It sets out rights to which patients, public and staff are entitled, and pledges which the NHS is committed to achieve.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A patient has a known allergy to penicillin. The doctor prescribes a drug from the penicillin family by mistake. The nurse notices this. What is the correct action?
Option b: Ask the patient if they feel lucky
Option c: Withhold the drug and question the prescription with the doctor
Option d: Give half the dose to see what happens
Explanation: The nurse has a professional duty to act as a safety net. They must not administer a medication they believe to be unsafe and must question the prescriber.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What does 'holistic care' mean?
Option a: Focusing only on the patient's physical symptoms
Option b: Treating the whole person, including their physical, emotional, social, and spiritual needs
Option c: Providing care only in a hospital setting
Option d: Following a strict care plan without deviation
Explanation: Holistic care is a comprehensive approach to patient care that considers all aspects of a person's life and wellbeing.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the leading cause of preventable death in hospitalised patients?
Option b: Medication errors
Option c: Hospital-acquired infections
Explanation: Venous thromboembolism (blood clots) is a significant and largely preventable cause of death in hospitalised patients. Risk assessment and prophylaxis are key.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A patient is being discharged. What is a key nursing responsibility in this process?
Option a: Ensuring the patient has transport home
Option b: Providing clear information about their medication, follow-up appointments, and who to contact if they have problems
Option c: Making sure the patient's bed is immediately available for the next person
Option d: Giving the patient a satisfaction survey
Explanation: A safe discharge requires providing the patient and their family with all the necessary information to manage their care at home and to know what to do if they have any concerns.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is 'person-centred care'?
Option a: Letting the patient decide everything about their care
Option b: A way of thinking and doing things that sees the people using health and social services as equal partners in planning, developing and monitoring care
Option c: A care model that is focused on efficiency and cost-saving
Option d: Providing the same care to every patient with the same condition
Explanation: Person-centred care involves putting patients and their families at the heart of all decisions. It is a partnership approach to healthcare.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the purpose of an incident form (e.g., Datix/IR1)?
Option b: To learn from incidents and near misses to improve safety
Option c: To protect the hospital from legal action
Option d: To provide data for media reports
Explanation: Incident reporting systems are not for blaming individuals but for identifying patterns and system failures, allowing the organisation to learn and improve patient safety.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: A nurse is asked to perform a task they have not been trained for. What should they do?
Option a: Attempt the task and hope for the best
Option b: Ask another nurse to supervise them
Option c: Decline to perform the task and explain they are not competent to do so
Option d: Read the procedure manual and then proceed
Explanation: Nurses must practice within the limits of their competence. It is essential to recognise this and decline tasks for which they are not trained, to ensure patient safety.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is the significance of the Francis Inquiry?
Option a: It led to the introduction of nurse revalidation
Option b: It highlighted major failings in care at Mid Staffordshire NHS Foundation Trust and made recommendations on patient safety and quality of care
Option c: It reformed the structure of the NHS
Option d: It changed the way doctors are regulated
Explanation: The Francis Inquiry was a major public inquiry that exposed serious failings in care and led to significant changes in the NHS, with a renewed focus on compassion, patient safety, and transparency.
SUBJECT: Not specified

Questions: What is atrial fibrillation?
Option b: A fast, chaotic heart rhythm originating in the atria
Option c: A type of heart block
Explanation: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a heart condition that causes an irregular and often abnormally fast heart rate. The upper chambers of the heart (atria) are quivering chaotically.

Questions: A patient is having an asthma attack. What is the priority nursing intervention?
Option b: Encourage the patient to lie down
Option c: Give the patient a paper bag to breathe into
Option d: Administer oxygen without a doctor's order
Explanation: The priority is to relieve the bronchospasm. Administering a prescribed short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) like salbutamol via an inhaler or nebuliser is the first-line treatment.

Questions: What is a key nursing consideration when caring for a patient with a urinary catheter?
Option a: Emptying the bag only when it is full
Option b: Keeping the drainage bag higher than the bladder
Option c: Regularly cleaning the catheter insertion site and maintaining a closed drainage system
Explanation: To prevent catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs), it's crucial to perform regular meatal care and ensure the closed drainage system is not broken. The bag must be kept below the bladder level.

Questions: What is MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus)?
Option a: A virus that causes skin infections
Option b: A type of bacteria that is resistant to many standard antibiotics
Option c: A fungus found in hospitals
Option d: A common skin bacterium that is harmless
Explanation: MRSA is a strain of Staphylococcus aureus bacteria that has developed resistance to several antibiotics, including methicillin, making infections harder to treat.

Questions: Which of the following is a classic sign of a wound infection?
Option b: The wound bed is pink and granular
Option c: Increased pain, redness, swelling, and purulent discharge
Explanation: The classic signs of a localised wound infection include redness (erythema), swelling (oedema), increased pain, warmth around the wound, and the presence of purulent (pus-like) exudate.

Questions: What is the definition of sepsis?
Option b: A life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection
Option c: A mild allergic reaction
Option d: High blood pressure due to infection
Explanation: Sepsis is a medical emergency. It's the body's extreme response to an infection, which triggers widespread inflammation and can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and death.

Questions: What is a key nursing consideration for a patient receiving oxygen therapy?
Option a: Ensure the patient does not smoke or use open flames nearby
Option b: Keep the oxygen flow rate as high as possible
Option c: Only use oxygen during the day
Option d: Remove the oxygen when the patient is eating
Explanation: Oxygen is highly combustible. The most critical safety precaution is to eliminate all sources of ignition, including smoking, candles, and sparks from electrical equipment, in the vicinity of oxygen use.

Questions: What is an electrocardiogram (ECG) used for?
Option b: To measure the electrical activity of the heart
Option c: To measure lung capacity
Explanation: An ECG records the electrical signals of the heart. It is a common and painless test used to quickly detect heart problems and monitor the heart's health.

Questions: What is a primary nursing goal in caring for a patient with a stoma?
Option a: To ensure the stoma is always covered
Option b: To change the appliance daily
Option c: To maintain the health of the stoma and surrounding skin, and promote patient self-care
Option d: To limit the patient's fluid intake
Explanation: Key goals include maintaining peristomal skin integrity, ensuring the appliance is secure, controlling odour, and empowering the patient through education to manage their stoma independently.

Questions: What is the main difference between Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes?
Option a: Type 1 is caused by diet, Type 2 is genetic
Option b: Type 1 is an autoimmune condition where the body doesn't produce insulin; Type 2 is where the body doesn't use insulin effectively
Option c: Type 1 affects children, Type 2 affects adults
Option d: Type 1 is treated with tablets, Type 2 with insulin
Explanation: In Type 1 diabetes, the body's immune system attacks and destroys the insulin-producing cells. In Type 2 diabetes, the body either doesn't produce enough insulin or the body's cells don't react to insulin properly (insulin resistance).

Questions: What is cellulitis?
Option a: A skin infection that affects the deeper layers of the skin and underlying tissue
Option b: A type of skin cancer
Option c: A viral rash
Explanation: Cellulitis is a common, and sometimes serious, bacterial skin infection. The affected skin appears swollen and red and is typically painful and warm to the touch.

Questions: A patient has a Braden Scale score of 12. What does this indicate?
Option b: Moderate risk of pressure ulcers
Option c: High risk of pressure ulcers
Option d: Very high risk of pressure ulcers
Explanation: The Braden Scale assesses a patient's risk for developing a pressure sore. A score of 12 or less indicates a high-risk patient, and preventative measures should be implemented immediately.

Questions: What are the "Five Moments for Hand Hygiene" as defined by the WHO?
Option a: Before patient contact, before a clean/aseptic procedure, after body fluid exposure risk, after patient contact, after contact with patient surroundings
Option b: When hands are visibly dirty, before eating, after using the toilet, after coughing, before starting work
Option c: At the start of a shift, at the end of a shift, before breaks, after breaks, before going home
Option d: Once an hour during a shift
Explanation: The '5 Moments' define the key times during patient care when hand hygiene is required to prevent the transmission of microorganisms.

Questions: What is the purpose of the surgical safety checklist?
Option a: To ensure the surgeon has the correct instruments
Option b: To confirm the patient's identity and the procedure being performed
Option c: To improve communication and teamwork to reduce errors and harm to the patient
Option d: To document the timing of the surgery
Explanation: The WHO Surgical Safety Checklist is a tool designed to improve the safety of surgical procedures by promoting effective communication and teamwork, and ensuring key safety checks are performed at critical stages.

Questions: A patient with a known fractured hip complains of severe pain, swelling, and tightness in their thigh. The nurse notes the leg is tense and pale. What serious complication might this indicate?
Option b: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
Option c: Compartment syndrome
Explanation: Compartment syndrome is a surgical emergency caused by swelling and bleeding in a confined space (a muscle compartment). It increases pressure and disrupts blood flow, potentially leading to muscle and nerve damage.

Questions: Which of these is a key principle of wound debridement?
Option a: To remove non-viable tissue from the wound bed to promote healing
Option b: To apply a dry dressing to the wound
Option c: To clean the wound with soap and water
Option d: To close the wound with sutures
Explanation: Debridement is the medical removal of dead, damaged, or infected tissue to improve the healing potential of the remaining healthy tissue.

Questions: What is the role of an advocate in healthcare?
Option a: To make decisions for the patient
Option b: To help a patient express their views and wishes, and ensure their voice is heard
Option c: To provide clinical care
Explanation: An advocate supports a person to understand information, make their own decisions, and express their views. They do not speak for the person, but empower the person to speak for themselves.

Questions: A patient with a tracheostomy requires suctioning. What is a key safety precaution?
Option b: Use a catheter that is half the diameter of the tracheostomy tube
Option c: Instill normal saline into the tracheostomy before suctioning
Option d: Apply suction only while withdrawing the catheter, for no longer than 10-15 seconds
Explanation: Applying suction for too long or while inserting the catheter can cause hypoxia and trauma to the tracheal mucosa. The procedure should be brief and intermittent.

Questions: A patient with a new spinal cord injury suddenly develops a pounding headache, high blood pressure, and profuse sweating. What condition should the nurse suspect?
Option b: A heart attack
Option c: Autonomic dysreflexia
Explanation: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency common in patients with spinal cord injuries above the T6 level. It is a massive, uncompensated cardiovascular response to a noxious stimulus below the level of the injury (e.g., a full bladder).

Questions: A patient is prescribed a medication '2mg SL'. What does 'SL' stand for?
Option b: Sublingual (under the tongue)
Option c: Saline lock
Explanation: SL' is the abbreviation for sublingual, meaning the tablet should be placed under the tongue where it dissolves and is absorbed directly into the bloodstream.

Questions: What is the primary purpose of medication reconciliation?
Option a: To check if the patient is taking their medication
Option b: To create a single, accurate list of a patient's current medications
Option c: To order new medications for the patient
Explanation: Medication reconciliation is the process of comparing a patient's medication orders to all of the medications that the patient has been taking. This is done to avoid medication errors such as omissions, duplications, dosing errors, or drug interactions.

Questions: In the context of safeguarding, what does 'making safeguarding personal' mean?
Option a: Only safeguarding people you know personally
Option b: Ensuring the person is at the centre of the safeguarding process and that their views and wishes are considered
Option c: Keeping safeguarding concerns confidential
Option d: Focusing on the needs of the organisation
Explanation: Making Safeguarding Personal is a person-centred approach that involves professionals working with the adult at risk to establish what they want to happen and to find solutions that are tailored to their individual circumstances.

Questions: A patient has a pressure ulcer that shows full-thickness skin and tissue loss, with exposed fascia, muscle, or bone. How would this be staged?
Option b: Stage 2
Option c: Stage 3
Explanation: A Stage 4 pressure ulcer is the most severe, involving full-thickness skin and tissue loss, where the damage extends to muscle, bone, or supporting structures.

Questions: What is the Waterlow Score used to assess?
Option b: A patient's risk of developing pressure ulcers
Option c: A patient's level of confusion
Explanation: The Waterlow Score is a widely used risk assessment tool that predicts a patient's risk of developing a pressure ulcer. It considers factors like BMI, mobility, skin type, and continence.

Questions: Which of the following is a key principle of breaking bad news?
Option b: Use complex medical terminology to be accurate
Option c: Ensure privacy, check what the patient already knows, and give information in small chunks
Option d: Be blunt to avoid giving false hope
Explanation: A structured approach (like the SPIKES protocol) is recommended. This involves setting up the interview in private, assessing the patient's perception, obtaining an invitation to share information, giving knowledge and information, addressing emotions with empathy, and summarising.

Questions: A patient is assessed as lacking the capacity to make a decision about their care. What is the next step?
Option a: A decision must be made in the patient's 'best interests'
Option b: The patient's next of kin automatically makes the decision
Option c: No decision can be made until the patient regains capacity
Option d: The doctor makes the decision based on their own preference
Explanation: Under the Mental Capacity Act 2005, any act done for, or on behalf of, a person who lacks capacity must be done in their best interests. This involves considering the person's wishes, feelings, beliefs, and values.

Questions: What is the role of a Patient Advice and Liaison Service (PALS)?
Option b: To help resolve concerns or problems when a patient is using the NHS
Option c: To handle formal complaints
Explanation: PALS offers confidential advice, support, and information on health-related matters. They provide a point of contact for patients, their families, and their carers, helping to resolve issues quickly before they become a formal complaint.

Questions: What is postural hypotension?
Option a: High blood pressure when standing up
Option b: A sudden drop in blood pressure when standing up from a sitting or lying position
Option c: A consistently low blood pressure
Option d: A drop in blood pressure during exercise
Explanation: Postural (or orthostatic) hypotension can cause dizziness and an increased risk of falls, particularly in older adults. It's caused by a delay in the normal constriction of blood vessels when changing position.

Questions: What is the primary aim of health promotion?
Option b: To enable people to increase control over, and to improve, their health
Option c: To reduce healthcare costs
Option d: To ensure people follow medical advice
Explanation: Health promotion involves a wide range of activities, including health education, preventative services, and creating supportive environments, to help individuals and communities lead healthier lives.

Questions: What is the main purpose of a multidisciplinary team (MDT) meeting?
Option b: To review the hospital budget
Option c: For a group of professionals from different disciplines to come together to make decisions about a patient's care
Option d: For nurses to report to doctors
Explanation: MDT meetings bring together different healthcare professionals (e.g., doctors, nurses, therapists, social workers) to share expertise and collaboratively plan a patient's treatment and care.

Questions: Which of the following is an example of a 'Never Event'?
Option a: A patient developing a pressure ulcer
Option b: A patient having a fall in hospital
Option c: A patient being given an overdose of insulin due to a known incorrect device being used
Option d: A patient complaining about the food
Explanation: Wrong route administration of medication is a specific 'Never Event'. The list includes serious incidents that are largely preventable if national guidance or safety recommendations are followed.

Questions: What is the purpose of an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate (IMCA)?
Option a: To provide care for people who lack capacity
Option b: To make best interest decisions for people who lack capacity
Option c: To support and represent people who lack capacity and have no one else to speak for them
Option d: To assess a person's mental capacity
Explanation: An IMCA is a legal safeguard for people who lack capacity to make specific important decisions, and who do not have family or friends who can be consulted. They ensure the person's rights are protected.

Questions: A patient on an IV drip complains of pain, swelling, and coldness at the cannula site. What is the most likely cause?
Option a: The drip is running too fast
Option b: The patient has an infection
Option c: The cannula has dislodged from the vein (extravasation)
Option d: The patient is having an allergic reaction
Explanation: Extravasation (or 'tissuing') occurs when the cannula comes out of the vein and the IV fluid infuses into the surrounding tissues. This causes pain, swelling, and coolness at the site.

Questions: What is the purpose of a clinical audit?
Option a: To find mistakes made by staff
Option b: A quality improvement process that seeks to improve patient care by comparing current practice against a set standard
Option c: To discipline underperforming teams
Explanation: A clinical audit is a systematic cycle of reviewing practice against criteria and then implementing changes to improve care, followed by re-auditing to see if the changes have been effective.

Questions: Which of these is a key principle of tissue viability?
Option a: To keep wounds dry at all times
Option b: To use the same dressing for all wound types
Option c: To provide a moist wound healing environment
Option d: To change dressings as often as possible
Explanation: Modern wound care is based on the principle of moist wound healing. A moist environment promotes cell growth and migration, leading to faster and better healing outcomes compared to letting a wound dry out.

Questions: A patient is refusing to eat or drink. What is the nurse's first action?
Option b: Document the refusal and do nothing
Option c: Try to understand the reason for the refusal and offer alternatives
Option d: Inform the patient's family and ask them to persuade the patient
Explanation: The first step is always to assess the situation. The nurse should gently explore the reasons for the refusal, which could be anything from pain, nausea, or dislike of the food, to a deliberate choice.

Questions: What is the main sign of a tension pneumothorax?
Option b: Tracheal deviation away from the affected side
Option c: A productive cough
Explanation: A tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening emergency where air builds up in the pleural space and cannot escape. The increased pressure pushes the mediastinum (including the trachea) to the opposite side.

Questions: What is the purpose of a 'Lasting Power of Attorney' (LPA) for Health and Welfare?
Option a: To allow someone to manage a person's finances
Option b: To appoint someone to make decisions about your health and care if you lose capacity
Option c: To write a will
Option d: To make a complaint about the NHS
Explanation: An LPA for Health and Welfare is a legal document where a person (the 'donor') appoints one or more 'attorneys' to make decisions about their care and medical treatment on their behalf if they are no longer able to.

Questions: What is the correct method for cleaning a wound?
Option a: From the dirtiest area to the cleanest
Option b: In a circular motion from the outside in
Option c: From top to bottom and from the centre outwards
Option d: Using a dry gauze to scrub the wound bed
Explanation: Wounds should be cleaned from the cleanest area to the dirtiest to avoid contaminating the clean part of thewound. This generally means cleaning from the wound itself outwards to the surrounding skin.

Questions: Which organisation is responsible for inspecting hospitals and care homes in England?
Option b: The Department of Health (DH)
Option c: The Care Quality Commission (CQC)
Explanation: The CQC is the independent regulator of health and social care in England. They monitor, inspect and regulate services to make sure they meet fundamental standards of quality and safety.

Questions: What is the primary cause of pressure ulcers?
Option b: Malnutrition
Option c: Prolonged pressure on a specific area of the body
Explanation: Pressure ulcers are caused by sustained pressure (and/or shear) on the skin, which cuts off the blood supply to the area, leading to tissue damage.

Questions: A patient is receiving end-of-life care. Their breathing pattern changes to periods of deep, rapid breathing followed by periods of apnoea. What is this pattern called?
Option b: Eupnoea
Option c: Cheyne-Stokes respiration
Explanation: Cheyne-Stokes respiration is an abnormal pattern of breathing often seen in patients with heart failure or stroke, and is also common as a person nears the end of life.

Questions: What is the purpose of a 'Freedom to Speak Up Guardian' in an NHS Trust?
Option b: To act as an independent and impartial source of advice and support for staff who want to raise concerns
Option c: To manage media enquiries
Option d: To provide legal advice to the Trust
Explanation: These roles were created to help foster a culture of openness and transparency in the NHS, where staff feel safe to speak up about any concerns they have about patient care, safety, or other issues.

Questions: A patient has a potassium level of 2.8 mmol/L. What is this condition called?
Option b: Hypokalaemia
Option c: Hyponatraemia
Explanation: Hypokalaemia is the term for a low level of potassium in the blood. Hyperkalaemia is high potassium. Hyponatraemia and hypernatraemia refer to low and high sodium levels, respectively.

Questions: What is the most appropriate way to communicate with a patient who has profound hearing loss?
Option b: Speak clearly, at a moderate pace, and face the person directly
Option c: Use complex written notes
Option d: Ask a family member to communicate for you
Explanation: Facing the person allows them to see your facial expressions and lip-read. Shouting distorts sound and can be uncomfortable. The communication should be clear and simple.

Questions: Which of these is a 'controlled drug'?
Option b: Ibuprofen
Option c: Morphine
Explanation: Controlled drugs (e.g., strong opioids like morphine, diamorphine) are subject to strict legal controls under the Misuse of Drugs Act due to their potential for harm and misuse. Their storage, administration, and destruction require special procedures.

Questions: A patient with dementia is agitated and pulling at their clothes. What is a possible reason for this behaviour?
Option b: They may be in pain, uncomfortable, or trying to communicate an unmet need
Option c: They need to be restrained
Option d: They are trying to get attention
Explanation: Behaviour in dementia is often a form of communication. The nurse's role is to act as a detective to try and understand the underlying cause, which could be pain, hunger, thirst, constipation, or fear, and address it.

Questions: What does the term 'nil by mouth' (NBM) mean?
Option a: The patient should only have water
Option b: The patient must not have any food, fluids, or oral medication
Option c: The patient can have small sips of water
Option d: The patient is on a liquid diet
Explanation: NBM is a medical instruction meaning to withhold oral food and fluids from a patient, typically before surgery or a medical procedure to prevent aspiration.

Questions: What is the main risk associated with a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)?
Option b: The clot dislodging and travelling to the lungs (pulmonary embolism)
Option c: The clot causing a stroke
Option d: The clot causing a heart attack
Explanation: A pulmonary embolism (PE) is a life-threatening complication of DVT. The clot breaks off, travels through the bloodstream, and lodges in the pulmonary arteries, blocking blood flow to the lungs.

Questions: What is a key principle of obtaining informed consent?
Option a: The consent must be voluntary and informed, and the person must have capacity
Option b: The doctor must sign the consent form
Option c: The patient's family must agree with the decision
Option d: Consent can be assumed unless the patient objects
Explanation: For consent to be valid, the person must be giving it voluntarily, without pressure. They must be provided with all the necessary information to make the decision, and they must have the mental capacity to weigh that information.

Questions: What is the purpose of an oral airway?
Option a: To prevent the patient from biting their tongue
Option b: To maintain a patent airway in an unconscious patient
Option c: To help a conscious patient to breathe
Explanation: An oropharyngeal (OP) airway is used in unconscious patients to prevent the tongue from falling back and obstructing the airway. It should not be used in conscious or semi-conscious patients as it can stimulate the gag reflex.

Questions: A patient is found to have Clostridium difficile (C. diff). What is the most important infection control measure?
Option b: Wearing gloves and an apron for all contact
Option c: Isolating the patient in a side room
Explanation: Isolating the patient is crucial to prevent the spread of C. diff spores. In addition, handwashing with soap and water is essential as alcohol gel does not kill C. diff spores. Gloves and aprons should also be worn.

Questions: What is the 'recovery position' used for?
Option a: To help a conscious patient feel more comfortable
Option b: To maintain a clear and open airway in an unconscious person who is breathing normally
Option c: To perform CPR
Option d: To manage a patient having a seizure
Explanation: The recovery position helps to keep the airway clear and open. It also ensures that any vomit or fluid will not cause them to choke. It is used for unconscious, breathing casualties.

Questions: What is the primary function of insulin in the body?
Option a: To increase the blood glucose level
Option b: To help glucose from the blood enter the body's cells to be used for energy
Option c: To break down fat
Explanation: Insulin acts like a key, unlocking the body's cells to allow glucose to enter and be used as fuel. Without enough insulin, glucose builds up in the bloodstream.

Questions: A patient is prescribed a 'statin' medication (e.g., atorvastatin). What is this type of drug primarily used for?
Option b: To lower cholesterol levels
Option c: To treat diabetes
Explanation: Statins are a group of medicines that can help lower the level of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. LDL cholesterol is often referred to as "bad cholesterol".

Questions: What is the purpose of a 'peak flow meter' for a patient with asthma?
Option a: To measure the amount of oxygen in their blood
Option b: To measure how quickly they can breathe out air, indicating how open their airways are
Option c: To deliver medication to their lungs
Explanation: A peak expiratory flow (PEF) meter measures how fast a person can breathe out. It helps patients to monitor their asthma control and can provide an early warning sign that their asthma is worsening.

Questions: A patient has a catheterised urine sample that is cloudy and foul-smelling. What does this suggest?
Option b: The patient may have a urinary tract infection (UTI)
Option c: This is a normal finding
Explanation: While dehydration can cause concentrated urine, the combination of a cloudy appearance and a foul odour is highly indicative of a UTI. A sample should be sent for culture and sensitivity testing.

Questions: Which of the following is a key aspect of care for a patient with dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)?
Option b: Providing thin fluids like water
Option c: Modifying the texture of food and fluids, and ensuring correct positioning during meals
Option d: Leaving the patient alone to eat
Explanation: Dysphagia management is crucial to prevent aspiration and ensure adequate nutrition. This involves a multidisciplinary approach, often including speech and language therapists, to determine the safest food and fluid consistency and feeding strategies.

Questions: What is the purpose of a 'venous thromboembolism' (VTE) risk assessment on admission to hospital?
Option a: To determine if the patient has a blood clot
Option b: To identify patients at risk of developing blood clots and to implement appropriate prevention
Option c: To assess the patient's risk of bleeding
Option d: To decide if the patient needs surgery
Explanation: All patients admitted to hospital should be assessed for their risk of VTE. This allows for appropriate preventative measures (prophylaxis), such as medication (e.g., low-molecular-weight heparin) or compression stockings, to be started.

Questions: A patient is due to have surgery. They state, "I'm not sure about this, I don't want to go through with it." What should the nurse do?
Option a: Tell them everything will be fine and proceed
Option b: Inform the surgeon that the patient is withdrawing their consent
Option c: Ask the family to convince the patient
Option d: Give the patient a sedative to calm them down
Explanation: A patient can withdraw consent at any time, even verbally. The nurse has a duty to respect this, stop the process, and inform the surgeon immediately. The patient cannot be forced to have the procedure.

Questions: What is the purpose of using a 'spacer' device with a metered-dose inhaler (MDI)?
Option a: To make the medication taste better
Option b: To improve the coordination between pressing the inhaler and breathing in, and to help more medication reach the lungs
Option c: To make the inhaler last longer
Option d: To mix the medication with oxygen
Explanation: A spacer is a plastic chamber that holds the medication for a few seconds after it has been released from the inhaler. This overcomes the need for perfect timing and allows more of the drug to be inhaled deep into the lungs rather than ending up in the mouth or throat.

Questions: A patient with end-stage renal disease is undergoing haemodialysis. What does this process do?
Option a: It adds fluid to the body
Option b: It removes waste products and excess fluid from the blood
Option c: It cures kidney disease
Explanation: Haemodialysis is a procedure to remove waste products like urea and creatinine, as well as excess fluid, from the blood when the kidneys are no longer able to do so.

Questions: A patient has a documented allergy to latex. What precaution is essential?
Option b: Ensure the environment is completely free of latex products
Option c: Administer an antihistamine before all procedures
Explanation: For a patient with a known latex allergy, it is crucial to use non-latex (e.g., nitrile or vinyl) gloves and ensure that all medical equipment that comes into contact with the patient is also latex-free to prevent an allergic reaction.

Questions: What is the normal range for a person's heart rate?
Option b: 60-100 beats per minute
Option c: 100-120 beats per minute
Explanation: For a resting adult, a normal heart rate is generally considered to be between 60 and 100 beats per minute (bpm).

Questions: What is the purpose of 'range of motion' (ROM) exercises for a bed-bound patient?
Option b: To prevent joint stiffness and contractures
Option c: To improve the patient's mood
Option d: To help the patient to sleep
Explanation: ROM exercises, whether passive (done by the nurse) or active (done by the patient), are performed to move each joint through its full range. This helps to maintain joint flexibility and prevent the permanent shortening of muscles and tendons (contractures).

Questions: A patient is unconscious and has no pulse and is not breathing. What is the immediate priority?
Option b: Start high-quality chest compressions
Option c: Insert an IV line
Explanation: In cardiac arrest, the immediate priority is to start cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), beginning with chest compressions, to circulate oxygenated blood to the brain and vital organs.

Questions: What is the main characteristic of a 'superficial' burn (first-degree burn)?
Option b: Redness, pain, and no blisters (like sunburn)
Option c: White, leathery skin
Explanation: A first-degree burn affects only the epidermis (the outer layer of skin). The burn site is red, painful, dry, and has no blisters.

Questions: A patient is taking a diuretic medication (e.g., furosemide). What is a key nursing consideration?
Option a: Monitor for signs of dehydration and electrolyte imbalances
Option b: Encourage the patient to limit their fluid intake
Option c: Check the patient's blood sugar levels
Explanation: Diuretics increase urine output, which can lead to dehydration and the loss of electrolytes like potassium. The nurse should monitor the patient's fluid balance, blood pressure, and check their electrolyte levels. They are usually given in the morning to avoid disturbing sleep.

Questions: What does the term 'aphasia' mean?
Option b: A language disorder that affects a person's ability to communicate
Option c: Memory loss
Explanation: Aphasia is most often caused by a stroke that has damaged the language centres of the brain. It can affect a person's ability to speak, understand speech, read, and write.

Questions: Which of the following is a key element of the 'Liverpool Care Pathway' (LCP)?
Option a: It is a recommended pathway for all dying patients
Option b: It has been replaced by individualised care plans
Option c: It focuses on aggressive treatment
Option d: It is used to hasten death
Explanation: The LCP was a generic pathway for dying patients that was phased out in the UK following criticism that it was too prescriptive and sometimes led to poor care. The current focus is on creating an individualised plan of care for each patient who is nearing the end of life.

Questions: A patient with a head injury has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8. What does this signify?
Option b: A moderate head injury
Option c: A severe head injury
Explanation: The GCS is scored between 3 and 15. A score of 8 or less is generally considered to indicate a severe head injury and coma. A score of 9-12 is moderate, and 13-15 is mild.

Questions: What is the main purpose of a 'fall risk assessment'?
Option a: To blame the patient if they fall
Option b: To identify a patient's individual risk factors for falling and implement preventative strategies
Option c: To restrict the patient's movement
Option d: To ensure the patient stays in bed
Explanation: A falls risk assessment is a tool to identify patients who are at risk of falling. Once risk factors are identified (e.g., poor mobility, confusion, certain medications), a personalised care plan can be put in place to reduce the risk.

Questions: A patient is found to be anaemic. What is the most common cause of anaemia?
Option b: Iron deficiency
Option c: Calcium deficiency
Explanation: Iron-deficiency anaemia is the most common type. It occurs when the body doesn't have enough iron to produce haemoglobin, the part of red blood cells that carries oxygen.

Questions: What is the role of an occupational therapist (OT)?
Option a: To help people with physical injuries
Option b: To help people of all ages to overcome challenges in completing everyday tasks or 'occupations'
Option c: To provide psychotherapy
Explanation: OTs work with people who have difficulties due to physical or mental illness, disability, or ageing. They help people to be as independent as possible in all areas of their life.

Questions: A patient complains of a sudden onset of severe, 'thunderclap' headache. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Option b: Tension headache
Option c: Subarachnoid haemorrhage
Explanation: A sudden, severe headache described as a 'thunderclap' headache (reaching maximum intensity within seconds to minutes) is the classic symptom of a subarachnoid haemorrhage, which is a medical emergency.

Questions: What is the correct procedure for taking a patient's blood pressure manually?
Option a: Use a cuff that is too small for the patient's arm
Option b: Place the stethoscope over the patient's clothing
Option c: Inflate the cuff 20-30 mmHg above the point where the radial pulse disappears
Option d: Deflate the cuff as quickly as possible
Explanation: To avoid under-inflating the cuff and getting an inaccurate reading, the cuff should be inflated to 20-30 mmHg above the estimated systolic pressure (determined by palpating the radial pulse). The cuff should then be deflated slowly (2-3 mmHg per second).

Questions: A patient with a history of heart failure complains of increasing shortness of breath and has swollen ankles. What do these signs suggest?
Option a: The patient has a chest infection
Option b: The patient's heart failure is worsening, causing fluid retention
Option c: The patient is dehydrated
Explanation: Worsening heart failure means the heart is not pumping effectively, which can lead to a build-up of fluid in the lungs (causing shortness of breath) and in the peripheral tissues like the ankles (causing oedema).

Questions: What is the purpose of 'protected mealtimes' in a hospital setting?
Option a: To ensure staff get their breaks
Option b: To allow patients to eat their meals without unnecessary interruptions from healthcare staff
Option c: To save money on catering
Option d: To make sure patients eat quickly
Explanation: Protected mealtimes is a policy to prevent non-essential interruptions during meals. This allows patients the time to eat and enjoy their food, and ensures that staff are available to provide assistance if needed.

Questions: A patient is prescribed '1 tablet PO OD'. What does 'OD' mean?
Option b: Twice a day
Option c: Every other day
Explanation: OD' (omne in die) is a Latin abbreviation meaning 'once a day'. Although still seen, it is recommended to write 'once a day' in full to avoid confusion with 'OD' meaning 'right eye'.

Questions: Which of the following is a key strategy for preventing pressure ulcers?
Option a: Keeping the patient still to avoid friction
Option b: Regular repositioning and use of pressure-relieving equipment
Option c: Massaging red areas of skin
Option d: Applying talcum powder to keep the skin dry
Explanation: The cornerstones of pressure ulcer prevention are relieving pressure through regular changes in position ('turning the patient') and using specialist mattresses or cushions that redistribute pressure. Red areas should not be massaged.

Questions: What is the purpose of a 'Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation' (DNACPR) decision?
Option a: To withdraw all treatment from a patient
Option b: To prevent CPR from being attempted when it would not be successful or would not be in the patient's best interests
Option c: To allow a patient to die from a treatable condition
Option d: To be made by the patient's family
Explanation: A DNACPR decision is about a specific intervention (CPR). It does not affect any other aspect of a patient's treatment. The decision is made based on clinical judgement about the likely outcome of CPR and the patient's own wishes and values.

Questions: A patient has a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube for feeding. What is a crucial nursing responsibility?
Option b: To ensure the tube is flushed with water before and after each feed or medication
Option c: To clean the site with alcohol
Option d: To use the same syringe for feeding and medication
Explanation: Flushing the PEG tube with water is essential to prevent it from becoming blocked. A clean technique should be used, and separate syringes should be used for feeding and medication to prevent contamination.

Questions: What is the main difference between 'delirium' and 'dementia'?
Option a: Delirium is a long-term condition, dementia is short-term
Option b: Delirium has a sudden onset and is often reversible; dementia has a gradual onset and is progressive
Option c: Delirium only affects young people
Option d: Delirium is a mental illness, dementia is a physical illness
Explanation: Delirium (or 'acute confusional state') develops quickly and its severity can fluctuate. It is often caused by an underlying physical illness (like an infection) and can resolve when the cause is treated. Dementia is a chronic, progressive decline in cognitive function.

Questions: What is the role of a physiotherapist?
Option a: To diagnose and treat conditions using physical methods such as exercise, massage, and manipulation
Option b: To provide counselling
Option c: To perform surgery
Explanation: Physiotherapists help people affected by injury, illness or disability through movement and exercise, manual therapy, education and advice.

Questions: A patient is receiving a blood transfusion. Which of these observations is most critical to perform?
Option a: Temperature, pulse, blood pressure, and respiratory rate
Option b: Pain assessment
Option c: Neurological assessment
Explanation: Vital signs must be monitored closely before, during, and after a blood transfusion to detect any signs of a transfusion reaction, which can be life-threatening. A full set of vital signs is typically taken before the transfusion starts, 15 minutes after it starts, and at regular intervals thereafter.

Questions: Which of these is a key principle of safe staffing in nursing?
Option a: Having the same number of nurses on every ward
Option b: Ensuring there are enough staff with the right skills and experience to meet the needs of patients safely
Option c: Having a high number of healthcare assistants and a low number of registered nurses
Option d: Letting the nurses decide their own staffing levels
Explanation: Safe staffing is not just about numbers, but about having the right mix of skills (the 'skill mix') to provide safe and effective care for the specific patient group on a ward at a specific time.

Questions: What is the role of a speech and language therapist (SLT)?
Option a: To help people with hearing problems
Option b: To assess and treat speech, language, communication, and swallowing disorders
Option c: To provide singing lessons
Option d: To teach people to speak a new language
Explanation: SLTs work with people of all ages who have communication or swallowing difficulties. They play a vital role in assessing a patient's swallow after a stroke to prevent aspiration.

Questions: What is the main purpose of oral hygiene for a patient who is nil by mouth?
Option b: To keep the mouth moist and clean, and to reduce the risk of infection
Option c: To help the patient to feel hungry
Explanation: Even if a patient is not eating, their mouth can become dry and colonised with bacteria. Regular oral care is essential for patient comfort and to prevent infections like ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Questions: A patient has a wound that is producing a large amount of exudate. What type of dressing would be most appropriate?
Option b: A film dressing
Option c: An alginate or foam dressing
Explanation: Alginate and foam dressings are highly absorbent and are therefore suitable for wounds with moderate to heavy exudate. Hydrocolloids and films are more suitable for low-exudate wounds.

Questions: What is a 'sentinel event'?
Option a: Any unexpected event in a healthcare setting
Option b: A patient safety event that results in death, permanent harm, or severe temporary harm
Option c: A minor incident that does not cause harm
Option d: An event that is expected to happen
Explanation: A sentinel event is a subcategory of adverse events. It is an unexpected occurrence involving death or serious physical or psychological injury, or the risk thereof. Such events are called 'sentinel' because they signal the need for immediate investigation and response.

Questions: What is the correct action if you discover a fire in a hospital ward?
Option a: Try to put out the fire yourself
Option b: Run away from the area
Option c: Activate the fire alarm and follow the local fire safety procedure
Option d: Close all doors and windows and wait for instructions
Explanation: The standard fire procedure is often remembered by the acronym RACE: Rescue anyone in immediate danger, Activate the alarm, Confine the fire by closing doors, and Evacuate or Extinguish if safe to do so.

Questions: What is the purpose of 'intentional rounding'?
Option a: To check on patients at set intervals to ensure their fundamental needs are being met
Option b: To complete all documentation at the same time
Option c: To have a round of drinks with colleagues
Option d: To perform a ward round with the doctors
Explanation: Intentional rounding is a structured process where nurses regularly check on patients to address key areas of care, often summarised by the '4 Ps': Pain, Personal needs (toileting), Positioning, and Placement of items.

Questions: A patient is prescribed a 'Pro re nata' (PRN) medication. What does this mean?
Option a: The medication should be taken at a regular time
Option b: The medication should be taken as required, according to a specific clinical indication
Option c: The medication should be taken before meals
Option d: The medication is a one-off dose
Explanation: PRN means 'as the circumstances arise'. A PRN medication is not taken regularly, but only when it is needed for a specific reason, for example, paracetamol for pain. The prescription must state the indication and the maximum frequency.

Questions: What is the main function of the Care Certificate in the UK?
Option a: It is a license to practise as a nurse
Option b: It is an agreed set of standards that health and social care workers should adhere to in their daily working life
Option c: It is a qualification for doctors
Option d: It is a certificate for hospital cleanliness
Explanation: The Care Certificate is an identified set of standards that health and social care workers should meet. It is designed for non-regulated staff, like Healthcare Assistants, to equip them with the fundamental skills to provide safe, compassionate care.

Questions: Which of these is a key part of managing a patient with neutropenic sepsis?
Option a: Withholding antibiotics until a diagnosis is confirmed
Option b: Administering broad-spectrum antibiotics within one hour of recognition
Option c: Giving the patient a high-fibre diet
Option d: Encouraging visitors to come and go freely
Explanation: Neutropenic sepsis is a life-threatening complication of cancer treatment. Patients have low levels of neutrophils (a type of white blood cell), making them highly susceptible to infection. The immediate administration of powerful antibiotics is critical.

Questions: What is the purpose of a 'body map' in documentation?
Option a: To draw a picture of the patient
Option b: To accurately document the location and characteristics of things like wounds, pressure ulcers, or injuries
Option c: To track the patient's weight
Option d: To plan a patient's exercise routine
Explanation: A body map is a diagram of the human body that allows a healthcare professional to mark the exact location, size, and shape of a skin lesion, wound, or other physical finding, which is more accurate than a written description alone.

Questions: A patient tells you they are taking a herbal remedy. What is the most appropriate action?
Option a: Tell them to stop taking it immediately
Option b: Document it in their records and inform the doctor and pharmacist
Option c: Ignore it as it is not a 'real' medicine
Option d: Tell them that herbal remedies are dangerous
Explanation: It is vital to know about all substances a patient is taking, including herbal remedies, as they can interact with prescribed medications. This information must be documented and communicated to the wider clinical team.

Questions: What is the role of a dietitian?
Option b: To assess, diagnose and treat dietary and nutritional problems
Option c: To help patients to lose weight
Explanation: Dietitians are qualified health professionals who use the most up-to-date public health and scientific research on food, health and disease to provide practical advice to patients, whether it's for managing a condition like diabetes or ensuring adequate nutrition.

Questions: A patient has a urinary catheter removed. What is a key nursing action following this?
Option a: To monitor the patient for urinary retention
Option b: To restrict the patient's fluid intake
Option c: To give the patient a diuretic
Option d: To re-insert the catheter if the patient has not passed urine within 2 hours
Explanation: After a catheter is removed, it is important to ensure the patient is able to pass urine on their own and is fully emptying their bladder. The nurse should monitor for signs of urinary retention (inability to pass urine), which may require medical intervention.

Questions: What is the primary purpose of professional reflection in nursing?
Option b: To learn from experience in order to improve future practice and patient care
Option c: To share gossip with colleagues
Explanation: Reflection is a key part of professional practice and revalidation. It involves thoughtfully considering an experience, identifying what went well and what could be improved, and using that insight to enhance your skills and quality of care.

Questions: What is the main principle of oral care for a patient who is unconscious?
Option a: To use a toothbrush and toothpaste
Option b: To keep the mouth and lips moist and clean to prevent infection and maintain comfort
Option c: To only provide oral care if the patient has teeth
Explanation: Unconscious patients are at high risk of their mouth becoming dry, leading to sores and infection. Gentle, regular cleaning with a soft swab or toothbrush and water-based moisturiser for the lips is crucial for comfort and to prevent parotitis.

Questions: Which of the following is a key sign of a urinary tract infection (UTI) in an older person?
Option b: Increased thirst
Option c: Sudden onset of confusion (delirium)
Explanation: Older adults may not present with classic UTI symptoms. New or worsening confusion is a very common and key indicator that should prompt a UTI investigation.

Questions: A patient has a 'skin tear'. What is the best initial nursing action?
Option b: Approximate the edges of the skin flap and apply a non-adherent dressing
Option c: Cover it with a large plaster
Option d: Leave it open to the air
Explanation: For a skin tear, the goal is to preserve the skin flap if it is viable. The flap should be gently rolled back into place, and a non-adherent dressing (like silicone) should be applied to avoid causing further trauma on removal.

Questions: What is the role of a social worker in a hospital setting?
Option b: To help patients and their families with social difficulties that may impact their health and wellbeing
Option c: To clean the ward
Explanation: Social workers can help with issues such as housing, finances, safeguarding concerns, and planning complex discharges by connecting patients with community resources and support.

Questions: A patient is having a panic attack. What is a helpful nursing intervention?
Option b: Leave them alone to 'ride it out'
Option c: Speak calmly and encourage them to focus on their breathing
Option d: Restrain the patient to prevent them from moving
Explanation: During a panic attack, a person can feel a sense of terror and loss of control. A calm, reassuring presence and simple instructions to slow their breathing can help them to regain a sense of control.

Questions: Which legislation in the UK provides the legal framework for safeguarding children?
Option b: The Children Act 1989 (and 2004)
Option c: The Health and Safety at Work Act 1974
Explanation: The Children Act 1989 is the primary legislation that sets out the duties of local authorities and courts to protect the welfare of children. The principle is that the child's welfare is paramount.

Questions: A patient with a known history of self-harm has superficial cuts on their arm. What is the nurse's priority?
Option a: To assess and treat the wounds while maintaining a non-judgemental attitude
Option b: To immediately refer them to a psychiatrist
Option c: To tell them they are wasting NHS time
Option d: To discharge them from the hospital
Explanation: The immediate priority is the patient's physical safety. This involves assessing the wounds, providing appropriate first aid, and creating a safe and trusting environment to allow for a conversation about what led to the self-harm.

Questions: What is the purpose of a 'medication reconciliation' on hospital admission?
Option a: To give the patient their first dose of medication
Option b: To ensure all of a patient's regular medications are safely continued in hospital by creating an accurate list
Option c: To decide which new medications to prescribe
Option d: To check if the patient is allergic to any medications
Explanation: Medication reconciliation is a formal process to create the most complete and accurate list possible of a patient's current medications and comparing that list to the admission, transfer, and/or discharge orders to identify and resolve any discrepancies.

Questions: A patient is prescribed a 'transdermal patch' for pain relief. What is a key instruction for its use?
Option a: Apply the new patch to the same spot every time
Option b: Cut the patch in half if the pain is not severe
Option c: Apply the new patch to a clean, dry, non-hairy area of skin and remove the old one
Option d: The patch can be worn in the shower and the swimming pool
Explanation: To ensure proper absorption and avoid skin irritation, patches should be applied to a different clean, dry site each time. The old patch must be removed before a new one is applied to prevent overdose.

Questions: What is a key principle of person-centred care?
Option a: The healthcare professional knows best and makes all the decisions
Option b: All patients with the same condition receive the same care
Option c: Care is tailored to the individual's needs, values, and preferences
Option d: The focus is on the patient's medical condition only
Explanation: Person-centred care is about treating the person as an individual and equal partner in their care. It respects their preferences and values and ensures they are involved in all decisions about their health and wellbeing.

Questions: What is the 'ABCDE' approach used for?
Option a: To assess a patient's level of consciousness
Option b: A systematic approach to the assessment and treatment of a critically ill patient
Option c: To assess a patient's nutritional status
Explanation: The ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) is a universal, systematic way to assess and treat a deteriorating or critically unwell patient, dealing with life-threatening problems first.

Questions: A patient has a wound with a large amount of dead, stringy tissue (slough). What is the process of removing this called?
Option b: Desiccation
Option c: Dehiscence
Explanation: Debridement is the removal of dead (necrotic) or infected skin tissue to help a wound heal. Slough is a common type of non-viable tissue that needs to be removed.

Questions: What is the purpose of 'clinical governance'?
Option a: A system to manage hospital finances
Option b: A framework through which healthcare organisations are accountable for continuously improving the quality of their services and safeguarding high standards of care
Option c: A system for managing staff performance
Option d: A set of rules for patient behaviour
Explanation: Clinical governance is about ensuring a safe and high-quality healthcare environment. Key components include clinical audit, risk management, staff training, and listening to patient feedback.

Questions: A patient is taking an ACE inhibitor (e.g., Ramipril). What is a common, troublesome side effect?
Option b: A skin rash
Option c: Constipation
Explanation: A dry, tickly cough that doesn't go away is a well-known side effect of ACE inhibitors and can be a reason for switching to an alternative medication like an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB).

Questions: What is the main principle of safeguarding adults?
Option a: To protect people from all possible risks
Option b: To protect an adult's right to live in safety, free from abuse and neglect
Option c: To make decisions for vulnerable adults
